poem:
### The Tides of Ink

Among clattering keys,  
a shift of pens,  
in the marble halls  
words turn,  
truth teeters.

Once giants strode,  
now whispers serve,  
echoes  
of tailored suits,  
bending light  
where shadows  
stood firm.

In the ink-stained rooms,  
pulp and bone,  
a question lingers—  
Whose voice  
speaks now?
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Mouthpieces for Trump’: inside the rightwing takeover of the Pentagon press corps Being a member of the Pentagon press corps was once one of the more prestigious assignments in US journalism, a position reserved for heavy hitters from venerable newspapers and news channels, reporters at the peak of their powers. Not any more. A press conference last week – held at a crucial time for a Pentagon embroiled in scandal – was instead attended by". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
